718098f-c.title: Manhattan: Carl Schurz Park - Gracie Mansion.
718098f-c.text:
Carl Schurz Park. A view of the Gracie Mansion, built in 1813 by Archibald Gracie and now (1937) occupied by the Museum of the City of New York. Samuel Provost, the first Bishop of New York and later president of Columbia, owned a farm of 90 acres here, the woodlands of which extended between 68th and 75th Streets and was called Jones Woods. Archibald Gracie bought this property from the heirs of Jacob Walton. His wife was Esther, a grand-daughter of Thomas Fitch of Connecticut.. Two other granddaughters of Governor Fitch married President TimotLy Dwight of Yale and Moses Rogers, Merchant, who built the house at No. 7 State Street. (present R.C. Mission of Our Lady of the Rosary) respectively. This set of four views show the front of the house that faces the East River. In the background appears a row of houses that are on the est side of East Ennd Ave.,
at Eaat 89th Street.
May 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
718098f-c.folder: Carl Schurz Park & Gracie Mansion., Manhattan, NY

May 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

718095f-b.title: Manhattan: Carl Schurz Park - Gracie Mansion.
718095f-b.text:
(1)
Carl Schurn Park A view of the East River frontage of the northern part of the park, with Gracie Mansion there in. Shown in tbe background are houses on the west side of East End Ave., and the spire atop a building of the House of the Good Shepherd; all at East 89th Street.
August 31, 1926.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A view of the south and east (front) sides of the Gracie Mansion as viewed northward from a point in the Park. The East River embankment
is on the right.
1932.
J. Clarence Davies,Collectiodn, Museam of the City of New York.
Negative No. 241.
od~
(3)
A view similar to No. 2. Note the foot path, benches, and general
improvements; a W.P.A. project.
March 29, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
718095f-b.folder: Carl Schurz Park & Gracie Mansion., Manhattan, NY

718082f-a.title: Manhattan: Carl Schurz Park.
718082f-a.text:
Carl Schurz Park: This park consists of 13 acres, east of East End Ave., (left) to the East River and extending northward from Gracie Square (East 84th Street) to East 89th Street. The northern portion of this park was known as "Horn's Hook" and figured very prominently in the wars of the Revolution and 1812. This northern tip contains a spacious house, known as Gracie Mansion; built in 1813 by Archibald Gracie and now occupied by the Museum of the City of New York. Playground, walks, skating rink, landscape gardening, building improvements etc; all are the work of the W.P.A. Notice on the right the new Triboro Bridge (a P.W.A. project) silhouetted against the curved span of the Hellgate
Bridge.
1936.
W.P.A. Photo
Federal Writers Project.

718086f-b.title: Manhattan: Carl Schurz Park (Northward).
718086f-b.text:
Carl Schurs Park: A view northward, from the northern extremipy of the Park, over the East River, and showing the new "streamlined" Triboro Bridge silhouetted against the curved span of the Hellgate Bridge. This set of 3 views are similar; No. 1, being of a slightly earlier date.
No. 1------March 29, 1937.
Nos. 2.& 3-August 17, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

718087f-a.title: Manhattan: Carl Schurz Park (Northeast).
718087f-a.text:
Carl Schurz Park: A set of 2 views northeastward, across tha.East River to Astoria, Long Island. Note the Hellgate (Long Island Connecting Railroad) Bridge on the left. In view No. 1 appears a pier at the foot of East 86th Street with a tug boat that conveys individuals to Welfare
(Blackwells) Island, tied thereto.
Spring 1924.
View 2:-June 24, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

718096f-a.title: Manhattan: Carl Schurz Park - Gracie Mansion.
718096f-a.text:
Carl Schurw Park: A set of 3 views of the Gracie Mansion, located in the northern end of the Park at what would be the foot of East 88th Street, if the street continued to the East River. This set shows the
front of the house, that overlooked the East River.
1913.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

718084f-b.title: Manhattan: Carl Schurz Park - Promenade; House of The Good Shepherd; United States Volunteer Life Saving Corps.
718084f-b.text:
(1) Carl Schurs Park: A view vestward on the Promenade, showing the Park on the left and the East River on the right. Beyond East End Ave., East 89th Street begins; upon the north side of which are the buildings of the House of the Good Shepherd. Note the U.S. Volunteer Life Saving
Station on the rivers edge.
August 2, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, from the northwestern corner of the Park.
May 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Cellection.
